School of Chemical Engineering, East China University of Science and Technology Shanghai 200237 PR China. A type of delaminated MWW zeolite is synthesized in the presence of hexamethyleneimine and dicyclohexylamine via a hydrothermal crystallization method. The appropriate molar ratio range of HMI/DCHA is found to correlate with the laminar morphology and crystallinity of the prepared zeolite samples. The delaminated MWW zeolite possesses thinner layered structure, larger external surface area and more accessible active sites than the conventional MCM-22 sample, and its protonated form can be used as a superb catalyst in benzene alkylation with cyclohexene. Under the optimized reaction conditions, the conversion of cyclohexene reaches 99.9 % while the selectivity to the target products, cyclohexylbenzene and dicyclohexylbenzene is 95.4 % in 1000 h lifetime experiment. Because of better diffusion properties and more abundant accessible acid sites on external surface, the delaminated MWW is superior to the conventional MCM-22 in benzene alkylation with cyclohexene, despite of the similar microporous structure and bulk acid properties of these two samples. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Delaminated MWW zeolite External surface Accessible active sites Alkylation of benzene Cyclohexene Cyclohexylbenzene 1 Introduction Cyclohexylbenzene (CHB) is a high value-added organic intermediate, which can be used as electrolyte additive of lithium-ion battery. It is also a raw material in the manufacture of liquid crystal display (LCD) [1,2], phenol/cyclohexanone [3,4], high-end plastics, coatings and adhesives, whose demand is gradually expanded by the development of its application fields [5]. Practically, CHB can be synthesized via alkylation of benzene with cyclohexene or cyclohexanol in the presence of a protonic acid (e.g. sulfuric acid, hydrofluoric acid, etc.) and/or a Lewis acid (e.g. aluminum chloride), but the process with these homogeneous catalysts has several problems, i.e. environment pollution and equipment corrosion, which cannot meet the trend of green chemical industry [6,7]. Zeolite, a kind of microporous material, can be used as a heterogeneous catalyst in some acid catalyzed reactions, such as alkylation, isomerization, transalkylation and disproportionation of aromatics [8,9]. The commercial processes for ethylbenzene [10] or cumene [11] manufacture in the presence of protonated ZSM-5, Y, Beta or MCM-22 [12,13] are good examples of the green applications of zeolites. However, few literatures have been reported so far on the alkylation of benzene with cyclohexene to CHB catalyzed by microporous zeolites, mainly due to the large molecular size of CHB, which could cause limited diffusion and consequently rapid deactivation of catalysts [14]. On the other hand, CHB can also be prepared by benzene hydroalkylation, which has been reported to have potential economic efficiency [15–19]. This process requires a bi-functional catalyst containing metallic active sites and acidic active sites, and is more complicated than benzene alkylation with cyclohexene [20]. The matching of the both active sites is still a problem to solve. MCM-22 is a typical MWW-type lamellar zeolite, whose precursors with loose bonding between layers show structural diversity and variability. MWW-type zeolite has two independent pore systems [21]: a 10-MR channel system (4.1 Å × 5.1 Å) within layers and a 12-MR supercages (7.1 Å × 18.2 Å) connected by 10-MR openings (4.0 Å × 5.5 Å). The 12-MR supercages are expressed as semi-supercage cups on the external surface [22]. MCM-22 is proved to be a highly active and selective catalyst in many organic chemical reaction, e.g. manufacture of ethylbenzene or cumene. However, once applied in the reactions associated with large organic molecules, rapid deactivation may become the main obstacle to the practical application of MCM-22, due to the diffusion problems. The most effective way to improve the catalytic performance of MWW-type zeolites is to expose more external semi-supercage cups without damaging them. The synthesis of delaminated zeolites with high external surface area and more external acid sites has become one of the most interesting topics in this research field [23,24]. By post-synthesis, ITQ-2 [25], a representative delaminated MWW-type zeolite, can be prepared by swelling and ultrasonic stripping of three-dimensional MCM-22 precursor in the presence of surfactants. However, the preparation procedure of ITQ-2 is considered to be complex, difficult to control and expensive. The situation of MCM-36 [26], developed by Mobil, is similar with that of ITQ-2. As a result, they are not suitable for a practical catalytic process. Therefore, one-step synthesis of delaminated MWW zeolites has attracted extensive attention [27,28]. Zhou et al. [29] directly synthesized disordered 2D MWW zeolites in the presence of cetyltrimethylammonium (CTA) surfactant. The disordered 2D MWW zeolites can be used in the alkylation of benzene with benzyl alcohol, in which conversion of benzyl alcohol can be increased by 30 %. Using hexamethyleneimine (HMI) and commercially available amphiphilic organosilane ([(CH3O)3SiC3H6N(CH3)2C18H37]Cl, TPOAC) as combinational SDAs, Chen et al. [30] studied the controlled direct synthesis of single-unit-cell (SL-) to multi-layered (mL-) MWW zeolite, and its high catalytic performance was demonstrated in the alkylation of benzene with 1-dodecene as a model reaction. In our previous work [31], a method for the direct synthesis of a delaminated MWW-type zeolite was achieved by introducing dicyclohexylamine (DCHA) as an assistant organic additive into the conventional synthesis system. This newly developed zeolite, named as SCM-1, can act as a highly efficient catalyst in alkylation of benzene with ethylene. However, the synthesis conditions, as well as the catalytic adaptability in alkylation of benzene with cyclohexene to produce CHB, has rarely been reported yet. In this paper, the direct synthesis of delaminated MWW zeolite using HMI and DCHA is carefully investigated. Herein, a comparison in the physicochemical properties, including the textual properties, the distribution of framework Al atoms and the external acidity, between as-prepared delaminated MWW zeolite and the conventional MCM-22 is demonstrated. Moreover, the delaminated MWW zeolite catalyst is tested as a catalyst in alkylation of benzene with cyclohexene to CHB and DCHB. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Delaminated MWW zeolites [31] and conventional MCM-22 [32] were synthesized using colloidal silica (Merck, LUDOX 40 %) and sodium metaaluminate (Aldrich, Al2O3 = 42 %) as silicon and aluminum sources, respectively. Hexamethyleneimine (HMI, Alfa Aesar, 98 %) was used as the organic structure-directing agent (OSDA), while dicyclohexylamine (DCHA) (Sinopharm, 97 %) was used as a delaminating additive. The precursors gels were prepared with molar compositions of 1.0 SiO2: 1/30 Al2O3: 0.04 Na2O: x HMI: y DCHA: 20 H2O, where x and y were variable from 0 to 0.8. Crystallization was carried out in teﬂon-lined stainless autoclaves under rotation (30 rpm) at 423 K for 2 d. After washing and filtration the solid products were then dried at 423 K overnight. The as-synthesized precursors were calcined in air at 823 K for 5 h to remove the organic species and were then ion-exchanged in 1 M NH4NO3 aqueous solution at room temperature for 4 times. After dried at 423 K overnight, the samples were then calcined at 823 K in air for 5 h and prepared as 20–40 mesh granules for catalytic performance test. In particular, the four representative samples denoted as M1 (x = 0.35, y = 0), M2 (x = 0.25, y = 0.2), M3 (x = 0.2, y = 0.4) and M4 (x = 0.15, y = 0.4) are synthesized according to the above procedure, where x and y represent the molar ratios of HMI to SiO2 and DCHA to SiO2 in the synthesis gel, respectively. 2.2 Characterization X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer equipped with a rotating anode and Cu-Kα1 radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å, 40 kV, 40 mA), with a scan rate of 2°·min−1. The scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were taken by a field emission scanning electron microscope (Hitachi S-4800, 2 kV). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were recorded on a Tecnai G220 S-TWIN (200 kV). Nitrogen ad-/desorption isotherms were collected on a Micromeritics ASAP-2000 instrument at 77 K. Samples were evacuated at 573 K for 4 h before measurement. The specific surface area and pore size distribution were calculated by the BET method [33] and BJH model [34], respectively, and t-plot curve method was used to calculate the microporous surface area and microporous pore volume. The SiO2/Al2O3 molar ratios were measured by chemical analysis in assistance of inductively coupled plasma (ICP) method. FTIR spectroscopy was used to characterize hydroxyl groups in various materials, the infrared spectrum was obtained by Nicolet Nexus 5700 FTIR spectrometer. The pyridine (Py-FTIR) and 2,6-di-tert-butylpyridine (DTBPy-FTIR) absorption infrared spectroscopy experiments were performed using a vacuum adsorption system followed by FTIR testing. All the samples were activated at 673 K in vacuum for 2 h. Adsorption occurred at 473 K in a saturated atmosphere of pyridine or 2,6-di-tert-butylpyridine for 10 min followed by degassing to less than 0.1 Pa. Then desorption was carried out at 473 K, 573 K and 673 K, respectively. Absorbance at specific wavenumbers was gathered to estimate the amounts of acid sites. 27Al MAS NMR and 29Si MAS NMR were performed on a JEOL 500 MHz (11.7 T) spectrometer using a 3.2 mm HX MAS NMR probe at resonance frequencies of 130.3, and 99.4 MHz and spun at a MAS rate of 18 kHz, respectively. The spectra were recorded after single-pulse π/12 and π/2 excitation with repetition times of 0.5 and 90 s for studying 27Al and 29Si nuclei, respectively. The 27Al and 29Si chemical shift scales were referenced externally using 1 M aqueous solution Al(NO3)3 at δ = 0 ppm and DSS at δ = 1.53 ppm, respectively. 2.3 Diffusivity property measurements The diffusivity of ethylbenzene (EB) and cyclohexylbenzene (CHB) in the zeolite samples were measured by gravimetric analysis method [35] using an Intelligent Gravimetric Analyzer instrument (model IGA-100) from Hiden Analytical Ltd., Warrington, UK. The calcined sample (0.10 g) was pretreated at a pressure below 10⁠−6 Pa at 573 K for 3 h to remove the adsorbed impurities before the sample held a constant weight. Afterwards, the sample was cooled to 373 K and the contacting gas was replaced by a preset amount of gaseous, consisting of EB or CHB. Isotherms and the corresponding kinetics of adsorption were determined at varied partial pressure (P/P⁠0 = 0–1). The effective diffusivity was fitted by Fick’s 2 nd Law [36]. MWW zeolite is a lamellar structure material, the solution of corresponding equation can be well approximated by Eq. (2–1): (2−1) M T M ∞ = 1 − ∑ n = 0 ∞ 8 2 n + 1 π 2 exp − D 2 n + 1 2 π 2 t h 2 Where ‘D′ is the apparent diffusion coefficient (ADC), ‘h′ is the layer thickness of the material, ‘M t ’ is the adsorption capacity at time t, and ‘ M ∞ ’ is the saturated adsorption capacity at equilibrium. 2.4 Catalytic performance testing The protonated samples (20–40 mesh) were tested in alkylation of benzene with cyclohexene. Catalyst samples (typically 5.0 mL, 1.50 g) were loaded in the middle of a stainless fixed-bed reactor with an inner diameter of 12 mm. At the beginning of reaction, the required reaction temperature and pressure were needed to be well adjusted before a mixture of benzene and cyclohexene was introduced to the reactor to initiate the alkylation reaction. The reactor was then brought to the reaction temperature of 373–443 K where the alkylation was operated continuously at 2.0 MPa, benzene to cyclohexene molar ratio at 10:1, the weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) at 3.65 or 18.2 h−1 for total feed, and the corresponding flow rate at 5.48 g·h−1 (6.30 mL·h−1). The reaction feed or effluent was analyzed by an online gas chromatograph equipped with a high pressure liquid sample injector, a flame ionization detector (FID) and a capillary column (HP-FFAP, 50 m × 0.2 mm × 0.33 µm). The conversion and selectivity were calculated according to the methods below. As the high pressure liquid sample injector can ensure a total component analysis for the feed or effluent, the conversion ( X ) of cyclohexene can be calculated by Eq. (2–2), in which “w” is representative to mass concentration of cyclohexene before or after reaction. (2−2) X Cyclohexene = w cyclohexene before reaction − w cyclohexene after reaction w cyclohexene before reaction × 100 % In Eq. (2–3), the selectivity to a specific product can be calculated, where "n < CH 2 > P ” is representative to the molar fraction of total “CH 2 ” group discounting benzene ring. The equation indicates how many cyclohexyl groups enter the specific product via alkylation, isomerization, oligomerization, cracking, etc. (2−3) Selectivity to a specific product ( P ) = n < CH 2 > P n < CH 2 > Total − n < CH 2 > cyclohexene × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physicochemical property of the MWW samples The influence of DCHA/SiO2 ratios to the crystallization products was investigated at a fixed HMI/SiO2 molar ratio of 0.25, and the XRD patterns are shown in Fig. 1. The pattern of MCM-22 (a) shows four intense peaks, at 3.2° (001), 6.5° (002), 7.8° (101) and 9.5° (102), due to interlayer diffraction about c-axis [23,37]. With the increase of DCHA/SiO2 ratio, the (001) and (002) diffraction peaks are weakened, and the (101) and (102) diffraction peaks grow weak and broad, indicating the disordered arrangement of MWW layers along the c-axis affected by DCHA [38,39]. The peaks at 7.5° and 26.0° are corresponding to (100) and (310) lattice plane, respectively, which represent the intralayer diffraction along a- or b-axis. Their intensities also decrease with the increase of DCHA/SiO2 ratio, which marks the slow rate of crystallization. When the DCHA/SiO2 ratio is higher than 0.6, MWW morphology is difficult to be formed. The amorphous product will be acquired, when DCHA/SiO2 ratio is higher than 0.8. As shown in Fig. 2, appropriate ratio of HMI to DCHA is found to determine the morphology of the crystallization products, from amorphous products to delaminated or conventional MWW. Among all the hydrothermally synthesized samples listed in Fig. 2, four representative ones, denoted as M1, M2, M3 and M4, were selected for comparison, whose XRD patterns are shown in Fig. S1. As the concentration of DCHA is insufficient (Fig. 2, M1), the molecules cannot be evenly inserted into MWW layers resulting in the rapid stacking of MWW layers along c-axis to form a conventional MCM-22(P) [32] morphology. On the contrary, as the quantity of DCHA is far beyond enough or the amount of HMI is low (Fig. 2, M3 and M4), the growth rate of MWW layers along a- or b-axis will be lagged. As a result, crystallization products in poor crystallinity will be got. The optimal molar ratio of HMI/DCHA is in the range is 0.56–1.25 (Fig. 2, M2), which can ensure to acquire a delaminated MWW zeolite with a high crystallinity. The SEM and TEM images of M1, M2, M3 and M4 are shown in Fig. 3. It can be observed that the samples, M1, M2 and M3, exhibit typical lamellar morphology of the MWW zeolite, while M4 is amorphous product, which is correlated with the results of XRD (Fig. S1). A considerable quantity of amorphous particles are observed in the image of M3 indicating its low crystallinity. At the same time, SEM images also show that the thickness and diameter of the lamellae of the delaminated MWW samples (M2 and M3) are obviously smaller than those of the conventional one (M1). This conclusion is consistent with the TEM results below. The TEM images of M1 and M2 reveal that the thickness of delaminated MWW sample (M2) is 2.5–5.2 nm indicating its mono-layered or dual-layered structure [40], which is obviously smaller than that of the conventional MCM-22 (M1, 11–20 nm). It can be inferred that DCHA can hinder the aggregation of MWW layers and cause their irregular arrangement. The physicochemical properties of the studied samples (M1, M2, M3 and M4) gathered by N2 physical ad-/desorption and chemical analysis are listed in Table 1. With the decrease of HMI/DCHA ratio, the proportion of external specific surface area increases (M4 > M3 > M2 > M1), but both the BET specific area and the microporous volume decrease, due to the lost in crystallinity. Under the appropriate HMI/DCHA ratio (0.56–1.25), the total pore volume reach the maximum for M2, while more inter-crystalline mesopores are produced by delaminated layer crystals. It is evident in M3 and M4, where their XRD patterns and SEM images clearly show the presence of weak diffraction peaks and an amorphous phases (Figs. S1 and 3), the microporous volume correspondingly decreases below 0.1 cm³ ·g−1 (Table 1, Vmicro), and the overall BET surface area monotonically decreases when increasing DCHA concentration (Table 1, Sext). Considering the good crystallinity and pore structure integrity of the samples, M1 and M2 are selected for physiochemical characterization and catalytic performance comparison. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of MCM-22 (M1) and delaminated MWW (M2) are shown in Fig. S2. Both isotherms are belong to Type IV with an H3 hysteresis loop, indicating the existence of mesoporous structure of the material. Compared with M1, there is a dramatic increase in adsorbed volume for the M2 where P/P0 is higher than 0.8, due to the disordered stacking of MWW mono-layers. And in the region of P/P0 < 0.1, a decrease of adsorbed volume is observed, which is correlated with its loss in microporous structure [41–43]. All the samples have similar SiO2/Al2O3 molar ratio around 31 because of their same feeding ratio of Si to Al sources. 3.2 Investigation of the active sites The active sites of the studied MWW zeolite samples were investigated via FTIR and NMR technologies. The FTIR spectra of the conventional MCM-22 sample (M1) and the delaminated MWW sample (M2) are shown in Fig. 4. MWW-type zeolite has a strong absorbance peak at 3745 cm−1 that belongs to the vibration of Si-OH group on external surface and terminal hydroxyl group; the weak peaks at 3694 cm−1 and 3663 cm−1 belong respectively to the stretching vibration of Si-OH group on internal surface and the group connected with aluminum outside zeolite framework; and the peak at 3620 cm−1 is due to the stretching vibration of acid bridge hydroxyl group (Si-OH-Al) in framework [44]. Compared with conventional MCM-22 (M1), the reflection at 3745 cm−1 of the delaminated MWW (M2) is significantly enhanced, indicating that M2 has larger external surface and more terminal silicon hydroxyl species because of its good delamination status. In addition, the absorption peak at 3620 cm−1 of M2 has no significant change compared with M1, explaining that the addition of DCHA does little effect on content of framework aluminum. According to the Py-FTIR results in Fig. 5, left, and Fig. S3, both samples show two discrete absorption peaks at 1545 cm−1 and 1450 cm−1, correlated to Brønsted acid sites and Lewis acid sites, respectively. The amount of Brønsted acid sites of M2 is slightly less than that of M1 at all the temperatures, and there is little difference in the amount of Lewis acid sites. It can be concluded that the bulk acidity of both the MCM-22 (M1) and delaminated MWW (M2) are quite similar, both in acid amount and strength. This result is also in accordance with the NH3-TPD patterns of the two samples (Fig. S4). Comparatively, because the molecule size of 2,6-di-tert-butylpyridine (DTBPy) is too large to enter the 10-MR micropores of MWW zeolites, DTBPy‐FTIR was carried out to characterize the external acid sites located in the semi-supercages of MWW zeolites. In the DTBPy‐FTIR patterns (Fig. 5, right), an apparent peak at 3370 cm–1 related to the external Brønsted acid sites is found in both samples. It is remarkable that the intensity of delaminated MWW (M2) is greater than that of the conventional MCM-22 (M1), indicating that delaminated MWW has a more abundant concentration of external Brønsted acid sites. The active sites of a protonated zeolite catalyst is usually associated with its amounts and status of framework Al atoms, which can be revealed by solid state NMR spectroscopy. According to the results of 27Al MAS NMR spectra in Fig. 6, there are two evident characteristic peaks appear at 56 ppm and 0 ppm after complete hydration of both M1 and M2. The resonance at around 0 ppm is typically assigned to extra-framework Al atoms (AlEF), whereas the resonance at 56 ppm is generally assigned to framework tetrahedral coordinated Al species (AlF). And it is found that at least three peaks are superimposed to get better fitting around 56 ppm. As it has been reported, framework Al of MWW-type zeolite is composed of 8 different tetrahedral sites (T sites) [29,44] that can be distinguished by 27Al MAS NMR spectroscopy and reorganized by three groups at specific chemical shift, i.e. three overlapped signals at around 50, 56, and 61 ppm, which can be referred to the (T6 +T7), (T1 +T3 +T4 +T5 +T8) and T2 sites, respectively [45,46]. The characteristic peak at 56 ppm (Al[56]) corresponds to the distribution of AlF in the sinusoidal channel, while the peaks at 50 ppm (Al[50]) and 61 ppm (Al[61]) correspond to the 12-MR supercage and the 12-MR semi-supercage cup on the external surface, respectively [47,48]. Comparing the calculation results in Table 2, the total AlF content in both the MCM-22 (M1) and delaminated MWW (M2) is quite close, but the Al[61] content (22.9 %) in M2 is much higher than that in M1 (13.8 %), which indicates that more AlF atoms are distributed on the external surface of delaminated MWW zeolites. According to the 29Si MAS NMR spectra shown in Fig. 7, most of the Si species are Q4 [Si(OSi)4] type due to the relatively high Si/Al ratio, and the specific assignments of this broad resonance are as follows: −105 ppm, −108 ppm, −111 ppm, −113 ppm, −115 ppm and −119 ppm, corresponding to the distribution of Si at different T sites in the zeolite framework. Small parts of Q2 [Si(OH)2(OSi)2] and Q3 [Si(1Al) and Si(OH)(OSi)3] are also found at approximately −90 ppm and −100 ppm [49,50], respectively. The proportion of Q2 and Q3 is about 7.5 % in the MCM-22 sample (M1), while it reaches 11.3 % for the delaminated MWW (M2) because of its abundant silicon species between two adjacent MWW layers. It can be summarized from the aforementioned characterization data that the delaminated MWW zeolite sample possesses thinner layered structure, larger external surface area and more accessible active sites than the conventional MCM-22 sample, which will be benefit to its application in catalysis, e.g. alkylation of benzene with cyclohexene. 3.3 Catalytic performance It has been also been reported that the delaminated MWW zeolite is a superb alkylation catalyst in benzene alkylation with ethylene or propylene [31]. As the alkylation agent was substituted by cyclohexene, the molecule size of the target product, CHB, will be much larger than ethylbenzene or cumene. As a result, higher requirement is demanded for the catalytic material, especially on its diffusion properties and accessibility of active sites. One of the key points to a good performance in benzene alkylation with cyclohexene is how to eliminate the mass transfer restrictions of molecules engaged in the reaction, so as to avoid side reactions and rapid deactivation of catalyst. As shown in Fig. S5, ethylbenzene (EB) and cyclohexylbenzene CHB, with different molecular sizes, were used as probe molecules to characterize the diffusion properties of both M1 and M2 using intelligent gravimetric analyzer (IGA) method. The slopes of the curves represent the diffusion rate of the two molecules. It can be observed that the diffusion rate of the two molecules for M2 is significantly greater than M1. The apparent diffusion coefficients (ADC) of two substances in zeolites are shown in Table 3. The ADC of EB in M2 is 1.7 times as much as that of M1, while the ADC of CHB is 3.9 times. In other words, the delaminated structure of M2 helps to shorten the effective diffusion distance and promote the diffusion of the probe molecules including CHB, a target product in benzene alkylation with cyclohexene. As a result, the excellent diffusion performance of the delaminated MWW sample (M2) plays an important role in the catalytic reaction. Alkylation of benzene with cyclohexene was carried out on conventional MCM-22 (M1) and delaminated MWW (M2) under 373–443 K, and the results are shown in Fig. 8. Compared with the conventional MCM-22 (M1), cyclohexene can be more easily converted over delaminated MWW (M2). The lowest temperature to ensure a complete cyclohexene conversion for M2 is 413 K, which is 10 K lower than that for M1. This can be attributed to the fact that delaminated MWW has more external acid sites than conventional MCM-22, although it has slightly smaller amount of bulk Brønsted acid sites. The variation of product selectivity with reaction temperature is shown in Fig. S6. It can be inferred that 423 K is the optimal reaction temperature, where the selectivity to CHB reaches the peak for both M1 and M2. The component composition and the product selectivity data of the conventional MCM-22 (M1) and the delaminated MWW (M2) in benzene alkylation with cyclohexene at 423 K is compared in Table 4, where the cyclohexene conversion of each sample is almost complete. Compared with M1, the delaminated MWW (M2) is found to be more selective to cyclohexylation products. The selectivity to CHB and DCHB reaches 95.4 % over M2. And it is remarkable that the selectivity to CHB (the most desired target product) is 88.7 % over M2, about 5 % higher than that over the conventional MCM-22 sample (M1), while the selectivity to DCHB (consecutive alkylation product) is 6.7 % over M2, about 3.3 % lower than that over M1. It means that CHB is easier to diffuse through the delaminated MWW sample to avoid consecutive alkylation than through the conventional MCM-22. Moreover, less side reactions take place on M2. Isomerization of CHB leads to form methylcyclopentylbenzene (MCPB) that has a close boiling point to CHB, and it is mainly determined by reaction temperature. As a result, the selectivity data to MCPB over M1 and M2 is quite close. However, the selectivity to the by-products of cracking, oligomerization of cyclohexene and other complicated side reactions over M2 (totally 2.7 %) is only about 60 % of that over M1 (totally 4.5 %) due to good diffusion properties and abundant surface acid sites of the delaminated MWW sample (M2). Side reactions are more likely to take place on the acid sites located at internal 12-MR supercages of MWW-type zeolite, where the diffusion rate of the organic molecules, especially CHB, is low. On the basis of the selectivity data in Table 4, a brief reaction network of benzene alkylation with cyclohexene can be speculated and shown in Scheme 1. In this reaction process, protonated MWW-type zeolite provides necessary acidic active sites either for the main reaction or the side reactions. According to the results of catalytic performance test in the present work, both the conventional MCM-22 sample and the delaminated MWW sample have good cyclohexylation selectivity to get CHB and DCHB. DCHB can be converted to recover CHB in the presence of benzene in another catalytic process, namely the transalkylation process. The estimated routes of side reactions are also listed in Scheme 1. Most of the by-products could be fractionated by rectifying process, besides MCPB. In order to evaluate the lifetime of the studied MWW-type zeolites, an optimized reaction condition (423 K, 2.0 MPa, benzene/cyclohexene molar ratio = 10, WHSV = 3.65 h−1) is applied to the stability tests of the samples (M1 and M2), and the dependence of cyclohexene conversion on the time of stream (TOS) and products selectivity in the early and last stages of the reaction are shown in Fig. 9(a) and (b), respectively, where all results were selected under the condition with high cyclohexene conversion. For the delaminated MWW sample (M2), the conversion of cyclohexene is maintained above 99.9 % (Fig. 9(a)), in the range of TOS before 1100 h, indicating its single lifetime, while the selectivity to CHB and DCHB is always at about 95 % (Fig. 9(b)). For comparison, the single lifetime of the conventional MCM-22 sample (M1) is about 520 h, about a half of that of M2. The faster deactivation of M1 can be attributed to its poor diffusion properties and less amount of external acid sites. As a result, larger amount of by-products are formed on M1, as is mentioned in Fig. 9(b, left), where the heavy components could became the precursors of coking and block the diffusion pathway and active sites. In addition, a rapid aging experiment of M1 and M2 was carried out at a higher WHSV (18.2 h−1 , 423 K, 2.0 MPa, benzene to cyclohexene molar ratio at 10:1). As shown in Fig. S7, delaminated MWW (M2) has a higher initial cyclohexene conversion and lower deactivation rate than conventional MCM-22 (M1), which is also accordant with the lifetime results in Fig. 9. In summary, it can be concluded that the delaminated MWW zeolite is superior to the MCM-22 in benzene alkylation with cyclohexene due to its better diffusion properties and more accessible external active sites, despite of the similar microporous structure and bulk acid properties of these two samples. For the development of industrial catalysts for CHB production, delaminated MWW zeolites could also provide a new research orientation and have a good prospect. 4 Conclusion A type of delaminated MWW zeolite is synthesized in the presence of HMI and DCHA, where DCHA acts as a stacking inhibitor of MWW layers. The optimal molar ratio of HMI/DCHA is in the range is 0.56–1.25 ensuring to acquire a delaminated MWW zeolite with a good crystallinity. The physicochemical properties of delaminated MWW were studied by means of various characterization methods including 27Al MAS NMR and DTBPy-FTIR. Compared with the conventional MCM-22 sample, delaminated MWW possesses thinner layered structure, larger external surface area and more accessible active sites. The protonated delaminated MWW zeolite is found to be a superb catalyst in benzene alkylation with cyclohexene, whose cyclohexene conversion can reach 99.9 %, while the selectivity to CHB and DCHB is 95.4 %. Moreover, it has a single cycle length about 1100 h under the optimized reaction conditions. Its catalytic performance is superior to the conventional MCM-22 due to its good diffusion properties and abundant external acid sites. It can also be predicted that the delaminated MWW zeolite could have a good prospect in an industrial process of CHB production in the future. coredata.dc:description: A type of delaminated MWW zeolite is synthesized in the presence of hexamethyleneimine and dicyclohexylamine via a hydrothermal crystallization method. The appropriate molar ratio range of HMI/DCHA is found to correlate with the laminar morphology and crystallinity of the prepared zeolite samples. The delaminated MWW zeolite possesses thinner layered structure, larger external surface area and more accessible active sites than the conventional MCM-22 sample, and its protonated form can be used as a superb catalyst in benzene alkylation with cyclohexene. Under the optimized reaction conditions, the conversion of cyclohexene reaches 99.9 % while the selectivity to the target products, cyclohexylbenzene and dicyclohexylbenzene is 95.4 % in 1000 h lifetime experiment. Because of better diffusion properties and more abundant accessible acid sites on external surface, the delaminated MWW is superior to the conventional MCM-22 in benzene alkylation with cyclohexene, despite of the similar microporous structure and bulk acid properties of these two samples.
coredata.dc:title: Delaminated MWW-type zeolite and its catalytic performance in alkylation of benzene with cyclohexene
